questions.text: What clinical test is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The clinical test depicted in the image is Cottle’s test where the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. 

This test is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve in patients with a deviated nasal septum. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve on that side.

Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV.

 

Option B: Heimlich manoeuvre is used in the treatment of accidental inhalation of foreign body. Procedure: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs can dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Option D: Trotter’s method is used in the treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter’s method, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood. He should pinch the nose firmly for 5 to 10 mins and breathe quietly from the mouth.

questions.text: In patients with urethral injury, where do you least expect the urine to get collected?
questions.solution:
In patients with urethral injury, the medial portion of the thigh is the least likely site for the collection of urine.

The superficial fascia of the abdomen is divided below the umbilicus into a superficial fatty layer (fascia of Camper) and deep membranous layer (fascia of Scarpa). Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the membranous layer of the superficial perineal fascia (Colles' fascia). 

Colles' fascia is attached to fascia lata (the deep fascia of the thigh) along the Holden's line that extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. Extravasated fluid cannot pass into the medial thigh below Holden's line due to the firm attachment of Colles' fascia to the fascia lata. 

Rupture of the urethra below the urogenital diaphragm will result in extravasation of urine into the superficial perineal pouch, the genitals and scrotum or labia majora and the anterior abdominal wall (see image).

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department after blunt trauma to the pelvis. Imaging revealed extravasation of the urine into the superficial perineal pouch due to the rupture of the spongy urethra. The attachment of which ​of the following fascia prevents the extravasation from spreading into the thigh and anal triangle?
questions.solution:
Colle's fascia prevents the extravasation of the urine from spreading into the thigh and anal triangle.

The deep membranous layer of Scarpa is continuous with the superficial fascia of the scrotum, the Colles' fascia. In the female, it continues into the labia majora and is continuous with the fascia of the perineum. 

The colle's fascia has the following attachments:

  • Posteriorly to the perineal membrane. It prevents the extension of fluids such as blood, pus, or urine into the anal triangle. 
  • Laterally to the ischiopubic rami. It prevents the extension of fluids into the thigh. 

Other options:

The superficial fascia of the abdomen has 2 layers below the level of umbilicus:

  • Superficial fatty layer of Camper
  • Deep membranous layer of Scarpa (which continues in the scrotum as Colle's fascia)

Bucks fascia refers to the fascia of the penis.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)  is the most common cyanotic heart disease encountered beyond the age of 1 year. It is characterized by a tetrad of:

  1. Severe right ventricle outflow obstruction
  2. Large ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  3. Aorta overriding VSD
  4. Right ventricular hypertrophy

In TOF, the hypertrophied right ventricle causes the rounded apical shadow to be uptilted so that it is situated higher above the diaphragm than normal. This on X-rays appears as a boot-shaped heart or Coeur en sabot.

Transposition of great arteries (TGA) is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Because of this, the pulmonary and systemic circulations remain separate. The cardiac silhouette usually has an egg-on-side appearance due to cardiomegaly and a narrow mediastinum. Normal to increased pulmonary blood flow is also seen. 

Ebstein anomaly is a rare cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by the downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. In some cases, there can be massive cardiomegaly resulting in a box-shaped heart. 

Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) occurs due to the anomalous connection of pulmonary veins instead of joining to the left atrium resulting in pulmonary venous blood reaching the right atrium. In supracardiac TAPVC the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resemble a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign.

questions.text: In a patient who is both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, what does declining IgM anti-HBc and rising total anti-HBc indicate?
questions.solution:
In patients who are both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, declining IgM anti-HBc and rising total anti-HBc are indicative of chronic infective hepatitis.

Anti-HBc IgM antibody signifies acute infection/window period, whereas, the presence of IgG anti-HBc indicates chronic infection. However, there is no test available to directly detect the IgG anti-HBC. Over a period of months, the IgM anti-HBc antibodies are replaced by the IgG anti-HBc antibodies. Thus a decline of IgM antibodies in the presence of rising total anti-HBC indicates that the IgM is being converted to IgG and thus the infection is chronic.  

HBeAg, HBV-DNA, and DNA polymerase appear in serum soon after HBsAg, and all signify active viral replication.

Occasionally, mutated strains of HBV emerge that do not produce HBeAg but are replication-competent and express HBcAg.

questions.text: The dose-response curve (DRC) is plotted for drug A both in the presence and absence of drug B.  What type of effect does drug B have on drug A?
questions.solution:
Drug B has a competitive antagonistic effect on drug A.

In competitive antagonism, DRC shows a parallel rightward shift. Competitive antagonism occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor. The response curve for the agonist shifts to the right in a concentration-related manner by the antagonist.

Other Options:

Option B: In non-competitive antagonism, there is flattening of the agonist DRC. Non-competitive antagonism effects occur when the agonist and antagonist bind to different sites on the receptor. ( allosteric site) and inhibits the response. The response curve progressively shifts in a right and downward direction until it reaches a limiting value when the allosteric site is fully occupied.

Option C: In competitive agonism, the curve shifts to the left.

Option D: In partial agonism, the partial agonist which has an affinity for the same receptor, also competes with and antagonizes a full agonist, while producing a submaximal response.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male met with a road traffic accident and is now having multiple episodes of vomiting.On examination , GCS was 10, he was drowsy and his blood pressure is high. Which reflex is responsible for elevated BP in this condition?
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for elevated BP in head injury patient is Cushing reflex.

As he has h/o head injury with fall in GCS and vomiting there might be associated intracranial bleed and thus the intracranial pressure will be elevated.

When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised, and the local hypoxia and hypercapnia increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure (Cushing reflex) tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms:

  • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
  • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
  • Irregular respiration (bradypnea)

Other options:

J Reflex

  • The juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors are C fiber endings located close to the pulmonary vessels.
  • These are stimulated when there is hyperinflation of the lung
  • Produces rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.

Atrial reflex control of heart rate: The Bainbridge Reflex

  • The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain
  • Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction

Bezold-Jarisch Reflex

  • Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery)
  • Causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

questions.text: Area marked "?" in the diagram below is ________.
questions.solution:
The image is of the floor of the 4th ventricle, and the area marked "?" is the hypoglossal triangle.

The floor of the 4th ventricle is diamond-shaped and lies on the dorsal surface of the pons and superior half of medulla.

It is divided into two symmetrical halves by the longitudinal median sulcus. Each half is further divided by sulcus limitans into a medial region, medial eminence, and a lateral region, vestibular area.

The vestibular nuclei lie beneath the vestibular area.

At the superior end of the sulcus limitans, a bluish-gray area is produced by a cluster of nerve cells containing melanin pigment called substantia ferruginea.

At the inferior end of the medial eminence, the fibers from the motor nucleus of the facial nerve looping over the abducens nucleus are represented by the facial colliculus.

Inferiorly, the medial eminence is represented by the hypoglossal triangle overlying the hypoglossal nucleus and the vagal triangle overlying the dorsal nucleus of vagus.

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked 'A' in the image is the Genioglossus muscle.

Genioglossus is one of the extrinsic muscles of the tongue which brings about the forward traction of the tongue to protrude its apex from the mouth. Hence, it is also called the safety muscle of the tongue.

Acting bilaterally, the two muscles depress the central part of the tongue, making it concave from side to side. Acting unilaterally, the tongue diverges to the opposite side.

Other options:

Hyoglossus: Depresses and retracts the tongue, pulling it downward and backward.

Styloglossus: Elevates and retracts the tongue, drawing it upward and backward.

Palatoglossus: Elevates the posterior portion of the tongue and narrows the fauces during swallowing.

Note:

  • All the muscles of the tongue except palatoglossus (cranial accessory nerve through pharyngeal plexus) are supplied by hypoglossal nerve.
  • All the muscles of pharynx except stylopharyngeus (glossopharyngeal nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of soft palate except tensor veli palatini (nerve to medial pterygoid from mandibular nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of larynx except cricothyroid (external laryngeal nerve) are supplied by recurrent laryngeal nerve.

All intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of tongue are derived from occipital myotomes, hence innervated by hypoglossal nerve, except palatoglossus which is derived from the pharyngeal arch and is supplied by vago-accessory nerve.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with growth retardation, recurrent attacks of hypoglycemia, doll-like facies with thin extremities and massive hepatomegaly. Blood examination reveals increased lactic acid, triglyceride, and uric acid levels. All of the following complications can be expected in this child except:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this clinical scenario is von Gierke’s disease. Cardiomyopathy is not a complication of von Gierke’s disease. On the contrary, cardiomyopathy is associated with Pompe's disease.

Enzyme deficient in von Gierke’s disease is glucose-6-phosphatase (common to both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis). Inheritance is autosomal recessive. 

Glycogen accumulation occurs in the liver and renal tubular cells. Clinical features include:

  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Ketosis
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperuricemia

A definitive diagnosis is made using a liver biopsy. Fructose and galactose restriction in the diet is advised.

Complications of von Gierke's disease:

  • Polycystic ovaries
  • Osteopenia
  • Hepatic adenoma
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Pancreatitis.
  • Renal failure.

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. His sputum sample showed acid-fast bacilli. What is the appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
In a patient with HIV and TB start ATT first and then start ART as soon as ATT is tolerated (between 2 weeks and 2 months) by the patient. This is done in order to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). 

Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS):

Patients with HIV-related TB may experience a temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ATT. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT.

It is characterized by high fever, lymphadenopathy, expanding intra-thoracic lesions, and worsening of chest X-ray findings. Diagnosis should be made only after ruling out treatment failure and other infections. For severe cases, prednisone 1-2mg/kg is used for 1-2 weeks and then gradually tapered.

However, in patients with CD4 <50/μL, the benefits of administering ART immediately after initiating ATT outweigh the risks of IRIS, and therefore ART should be started as early as possible.

Note: As per RNTCP guidelines, CBNAAT is the preferred diagnostic technique for testing TB in PLHIV (people living with HIV). Smear microscopy has poor sensitivity in detecting TB in PLHIV due to fewer organisms in sputum, and hence is not preferred.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child post-tonsillectomy comes to you with complaints of snoring, palpitations, mouth breathing and a slight decrease in hearing. On examination, you notice a high-arched palate. His school performance has deteriorated as well. His mother is worried. What is the next line of management for this child?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy causing eustachian tube obstruction. The best line of management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

Serous otitis media is also known as secretory otitis media or mucoid otitis media or glue ear. It is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft. 

Glue ear is thought to happen due to either malfunctioning (adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx) or increased secretory activity of the eustachian tube (allergy, unresolved otitis media, viral infections).

It is often seen in children 5-8 years of age. They present with hearing loss not exceeding 40 dB, which is insidious in onset. Speech may be delayed and defective due to hearing loss. Mild earaches with a history of upper respiratory tract infection are usually seen. 

On otoscopy, 

  • Dull and opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex
  • Thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus 
  • If the tympanic membrane is transparent fluid levels and air bubbles can be seen

 

The tuning fork test reveals a conductive type of hearing loss. X-ray mastoid reveals clouding of air cells. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at the removal of fluid and preventing recurrence. 

  • Medical management includes decongestants, antihistamines, antibiotics, and middle ear aeration techniques. 
  • Surgical management includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid, grommet insertion, tympanotomy, or cortical mastoidectomy.

questions.text: A  newborn had hypoplasia of the mandibles and zygomatic bones, malformed external ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal arches will most likely​ lead to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Treacher-Collins syndrome results from abnormal development of the 1st pharyngeal arch (mandibular arch). 

First-arch syndromes are congenital defects caused due to the failure of the neural crest cells to migrate into the 1st pharyngeal arch. 

  • Treacher-Collins syndrome (mandibulo-facial dysostosis) is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder. It is characterized by:
    • Craniofacial bone defects involving the mandible (causing micrognathia), maxilla, and zygomatic arches
    • Ear defects involving the external ear, atresia of auditory canals, and abnormalities of the middle ear ossicles, leading to bilateral conductive hearing loss
    • Eye defects such as down-slanting palpebral fissures and lower eyelid colobomas
  • Pierre Robin sequence (or Robin sequence) is a deformity seen in 1/8500 births. It may be caused due to genetic defects or due to environmental factors. It can also be seen in oligohydramnios when the chin gets compressed against the chest in utero. 
    • It is characterized by a triad of micrognathia, glossoptosis (posteriorly placed tongue), and cleft palate.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent hemoptysis and renal failure undergoes a renal biopsy, which reveals presence of crescents in most of the glomeruli. Immunofluorescence reveals linear deposits of IgG and C3. The diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
Pulmonary hemorrhage associated with renal failure, crescentic glomerulonephritis, and linear deposits of IgG and C3 in the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) are all seen in Goodpasture syndrome.

It is anti-GBM antibody-mediated disease against the antigen within the noncollagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV common to the alveoli and GBM.

About one-fifths of the patients with RPGN have anti-GBM antibody-mediated glomerulonephritis.

Other options:

  1. Post-infectious glomerulonephritis: Granular IgG and C3 deposits
  2. Membranous nephropathy: granular IgG and C3 deposits; do not form crescents
  3. Wegener granulomatosis: absence of immune complex deposits on immunofluorescence; causes pauci-immune rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient who is on medication for benign prostatic hyperplasia was posted for cataract surgery. Intraoperatively, the surgeon noticed a floppy iris with progressive intraoperative pupillary constriction. Which of the following is the most likely drug responsible for the above features?
questions.solution:
The most likely drug responsible for the above features is tamsulosin.

The above clinical scenario with a history of medication for benign prostatic hyperplasia and the intraoperative finding of floppy iris with progressive pupillary constriction is suggestive of floppy iris syndrome. Tamsulosin causes floppy iris syndrome.

Tamsulosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A and α1D receptors. This selectivity causes a blockade of the α1A receptor in the prostate. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. It has very little effect on blood pressure due to its selective effect on α1A and α1D and hence is not used in the treatment of hypertension.

Some of the adverse effects of tamsulosin include orthostatic hypotension, abnormal ejaculation, and floppy iris syndrome.

Intraoperative floppy iris syndrome is characterized by a triad of the following features:

  • flaccid iris billowing through the surgical incision
  • iris prolapse
  • intraoperative pupillary constriction

Examples of other drugs causing floppy iris syndrome include finasteride, benzodiazepines, donepezil, and duloxetine. Some α1 receptor antagonists like alfuzosin, doxazosin, and terazosin are associated with floppy iris syndrome but have a very low risk compared to tamsulosin.

Other options:

Option B- Prazosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with equal potency to all the subtypes of α1 receptor. It is used in the treatment of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia(BPH). Prazosin causes orthostatic hypotension after its initial dose.

Option C- Silodosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with more selectivity over the α1 subtype. It is approved in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia with lesser effects on blood pressure. The main adverse effect is retrograde ejaculation. Dizziness and orthostatic hypotension can also be seen.

Option D- Dutasteride is a 5α-reductase inhibitor that blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. It is approved in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Impotence is a documented side effect and gynecomastia is a rare side effect.

questions.text: Which monoclonal antibody is used in cancer treatment?
questions.solution:
Rituximab is an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody and is used in the treatment of lymphomas.

  • Rituximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody that targets the CD20 B-cell antigen. CD20 is found in cells from the pre–B cell stage through its terminal differentiation to plasma cells and is expressed in 90% of B-cell neoplasms.
  • Monoclonal antibody binding to CD20 generates transmembrane signals that produce autophosphorylation and activation of serine/tyrosine protein kinases, induction of c-Myc oncogene expression, and expression of major histocompatibility complex class II molecules.
  • Rituximab is approved as a single agent for relapsed indolent lymphomas and significantly enhances response and survival in combination with chemotherapy for the initial treatment of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma(DLBCL).
  • It remains effective in patients who relapse after initial treatment with rituximab-based combinations.
  • Rituximab improves response rates when added to combination chemotherapy for other indolent B-cell non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas (NHLs), including CLL, mantle cell lymphoma, Waldenström macroglobulinemia, and marginal zone lymphomas.

Note:

Monoclonal antibodies recognize the extracellular domain of the EGFR, inhibit ligand-induced signalling, and can elicit an immune response. Cetuximab is a recombinant, chimeric human/mouse IgG1 antibody that binds to EGFR and prevents ligand-dependent signalling and receptor dimerization, thereby blocking cell growth and survival signals. It is used to treat patients with metastatic colon cancers and Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma(HNSCC)

questions.text: A 60-year-old male came to the hospital with complaints of diplopia, and progressive headache. Examination of extraocular movements revealed the findings as shown in the image, when the patient attempted to look right. Lesion involving which cranial nerve marked in the image below is likely to cause the condition, and which eye is affected?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding shown in the image is suggestive of lateral rectus palsy of the right eye, which occurs due to the lesion involving right abducens nerve. In the given image, showing the base of the brain, the right abducens nerve is marked as ‘3’.

The Abducens nerve arises from the brainstem between the pons and medulla oblongata. It enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure and innervates the lateral rectus muscle through its medial (ocular surface).

Determining the palsy:

The abduction and adduction of the eye are caused by the action of the lateral rectus and medial rectus muscles respectively.

The lateral rectus is innervated by abducens nerve (VI) while the medial rectus is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (III).

Horizontal conjugate movements occur when both eyes moves horizontally to look right or left.

  • In right gaze: The right eye abducts and the left eye adducts.
  • In left gaze: The right eye adducts and the left eye abducts.

In the image, when the patient attempted to look right, the left eye adducted normally, while the right eye failed to abduct. This is suggestive of right lateral rectus palsy due to the lesion involving the right abducens nerve.

Note: If the same finding as shown in the image is seen when the patient is looking straight (neutral gaze), then the affected eye is the left eye. In such case, due to left lateral rectus palsy, the action of left medial rectus is unopposed causing adduction of the left eye.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with craniotabes, rachitic rosary and his Xray of both knees are shown below. Which of the following is deficient in this disease?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is  rickets and deficiency of 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol /Calcitriol ( biologically active form of Vit D) is seen in rickets.

The symptoms of craniotabes, rachitic rosary along with the xray finding of  bowing of legs makes Rickets the most likely diagnosis.

 Vitamin D, as either cholecalciferol or ergocalciferol does not have significant biological activity. It is activated as follows:

  • Step 1: Skin: 7-Dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in the synthesis of cholesterol in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light (290nm to 315nm), yielding cholecalciferol.
  • Step 2: Liver:  Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (the most abundant circulatory form of Vitamin D) by the enzyme 25-hydroxylase.
  • Step 3: Kidney: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), the biologically active form by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase.

Calcitriol acts on the bone, intestine and kidney to maintain calcium and phosphate homeostasis.

Note: if the body does not require vitamin-D, in the kidney, 24-hydroxylase converts vitamin D into 24,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, which is an inactive metabolite.

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis.
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.
  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification (becomes denser in healing rickets, known as the white line of Frenkel).

questions.text: A patient died due to encephalitis. A postmortem biopsy of the brain tissue is shown below. This finding is characteristic of infection caused by:
questions.solution:
The finding in the image shows Negri bodies, which is characteristic of the infection caused by the rabies virus.

Negri bodies are pathognomonic of rabies virus infection. These are spherical-shaped cytoplasmic inclusion bodies. They contain eosinophilic matrix, basophilic granules, and viral antigens. 

Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. These viruses are enveloped, rod or bullet shaped, and contain single-stranded RNA.

Clinical features of rabies can be categorized into three phases: prodromal, encephalitic phase, and coma. Prodromal phase is characterised by malaise, anorexia, headache, and irritability. This is followed by the encephalitic stage characterized by abnormal behavior and seizures. They develop hydrophobia. Attempts to drink liquids cause painful spasms of the pharynx and larynx, producing a choking sensation. Therefore, the patients develop a phobia of even the sight or sound of water. Finally, seizures, coma, and death occur.

Laboratory diagnosis can be done on a postmortem or antemortem basis. Postmortem diagnosis is done by the demonstration of Negri bodies. These bodies are common in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. Antemortem diagnosis is done from corneal scrapings, saliva, or skin biopsy. Demonstration of the virus is done using direct immunofluorescence. 

Other methods used in the diagnosis are intracerebral inoculation in the mice, tissue culture, ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay), and PCR (polymerase chain reaction).

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of rice-water stools is suggestive of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced by the organism acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors.

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice water stools) associated with effortless vomiting. Pulmonary edema and arrhythmias are some of the complications. 

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhea. 

In addition to the cholera toxin, additional toxins such as zona occludens toxin and accessory cholera toxin are also produced. The former alters intestinal permeability by its action on intestinal epithelial cells.

The characteristic darting mobility and its hindrance by antiserum can be used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

Fluid resuscitation by rice-based ORS is recommended. Medical management includes erythromycin or azithromycin.

Macrophages are involved in chronic inflammatory reactions, where they secrete cytokines and growth factors that eliminate microbes and damaged tissues and activate T lymphocytes. They are also involved in tissue repair. Macrophages are activated via two pathways:

  • Classical pathway: In this pathway, macrophages are activated by cytokine IFN-Ɣ secreted by Th1 cells, microbial products (endotoxin), T cell-derived signals, or foreign substances. These macrophages play an important role in host defense and inflammatory reactions. 
  • Alternate pathway: In this pathway, macrophages are activated by cytokines like IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 secreted by Th2 cells. These macrophages are primarily involved in tissue repair. 

T-lymphocytes and macrophages show a bidirectional interaction, where lymphocytes produce cytokines that activate macrophages and activated macrophages produce cytokines to stimulate T-lymphocyte responses.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with swelling in the upper diaphyseal part of the tibia. X-ray of the swelling showed a periosteal reaction. A histopathological image of the biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry was positive for synaptophysin and mic 2. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing small round blue cells and immunohistochemistry (IHC) positive for synaptophysin and mic-2 point to a likely diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma. 

Ewing sarcoma is the 2nd most common bone sarcoma in children. The majority of the patients affected are usually <20 years of age. It has a slight male predominance. 

It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus and flat bones of the pelvis. The majority of Ewing sarcomas have t(11:22). 

Patients present with painful enlarging mass, fever, and anaemia. The affected area is usually tender, swollen, and warm. Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). 

A histopathological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows sheets of uniform, round cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes. These cells are of neuroectodermal origin and have minimal cytoplasm and abundant glycogen. When they are arranged around a central fibrillary core in the form of clusters, the appearance is termed Homer-Wright rosettes. Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for synaptophysin and mic-2.

Given below is the histopathological appearance of Ewing sarcoma. 

As tumor cells are rich in glycogen, they stain positive for periodic acid Schiff (PAS) stain however, they stain negatively for reticulin.

Radiological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. Deposition of periosteal reaction in layers gives an onion-peel appearance (shown below). 

Other options:

Option A: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone. The histological features of osteosarcoma include pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant mitoses. The diagnosis is definitive with the presence of malignant tumor cells producing unmineralized osteoid or mineralized bone arranged in a typically fine, lacelike pattern.

X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunray appearance as shown below.

Option C: Neuroblastoma is a tumor of the sympathetic ganglia and adrenal medulla. It is derived from primordial neural crest cells. It is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood. On histopathology, small round blue cells are seen. These cells are concentrically arranged around a faintly eosinophilic fibrillary material (neuropil). This appearance is called Homer-Wright pseudorosettes

Option D: Osteoclastoma is also known as a giant cell tumour. The tumor cells are primitive osteoblast precursors and express high levels of RANKL. Histologically, the tumors consist of osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei. These cells are usually present against a backdrop of mononuclear stromal cells as shown below.

The image below shows an X-ray of a giant cell tumour showing the typical soap bubble appearance.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about group discussion?

choices.text: One topic is spoken about in one discussion.
One group leader for every 3 poeple.
It usually consists of 2 to 4 people.

questions.solution:
A group discussion discusses one topic on its agenda.

Group discussion is an aggregation of people interacting in a face to face manner.

  • Exchange of ideas, knowledge, and opinions is done by participants which influences a change in their attitudes.
  • It usually involves 6–12 people with a group leader who guides the conversation, giving equal opportunity to everyone to voice themselves.
  • In a group discussion, everyone must speak and be open to criticism without interruption of another.
  • Limitation – not everyone is open to speaking in public and possibility of diversion of topic of discussion is high when many people are involved.

Waters' view (also known as the Occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view, where an X-ray beam is angled at 37° to the orbitomeatal line. The rays are passed from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  • It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Structures observed:

  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (through open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone

Caldwell's view (also known as the occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is a radiographic view of the skull, where the X-ray plate is angled at 15° to the orbito-meatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  • It is commonly used to get a better view of frontal sinuses.

Structures seen are: 

  • Frontal sinuses 
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

The image below shows Caldwell's view 

Towne's view: 

It is taken with the patient in the supine position and lying on his back with the chin often depressed into the neck. The X-ray camera is angled at 30 degrees towards the feet so that the rays enter the head at the level of the hairline.

  • This is usually taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.
  • Bilateral petrous pyramids are visible in this view and hence can be compared.

  • Mastoid antrum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man undergoing treatment for TB visits your OPD for a follow-up. His wife states that recently he keeps forgetting the names of his colleagues and neighbors, but later recollects them correctly. Which drug is implicated to cause this condition?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following is a synthetic pyrethroid insecticide?
questions.solution:
Permethrin is a synthetic pyrethroid. Pyrethroids are synthetic insecticides, which are derived from naturally occurring pyrethrins. Pyrethroids modify the sodium channels in neuronal membranes and thereby disrupt the electrical signalling in the nervous system. 

Permethrin is effective in killing or repelling insects and is often used in products like insect repellent sprays, creams, and treated clothing for personal protection against insect bites.

Other options:

  • Propoxur is not a synthetic pyrethroid insecticide. It is a carbamate insecticide used for pest control.
  • Parathion is not a pyrethroid insecticide either. It is an organophosphorus insecticide, which works differently from pyrethroids.
  • Pyrolan is not a commonly known insecticide and is not a synthetic pyrethroid.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass filled the nasal cavity and eroded the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

Diabetic patients with local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discolouration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

Risk factors:

  • Diabetes (diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Treatment:

  • Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.
  • Surgical debridement
  • Control of underlying predisposing causes.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of black or greyish membrane in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: A patient presented with swelling in the buccal cavity. A biopsy of the tissue was done and the histological image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histological image shows both epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right), which is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms. The parotid gland is the most common site. The submandibular and minor salivary glands are the less common sites. They present as painless, slow-growing, mobile, discrete masses within the parotid or submandibular areas or in the buccal cavity.

Gross features- The tumors are rounded and well-demarcated. They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate. The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

Microscopic features consist of:

  • The epithelial elements- They resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells. They are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells.
  • Mesenchymal elements consisting of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

Other options: 

Option A - Oncocytomas arise from the kidneys. They are epithelial neoplasms that are composed of large eosinophilic cells with small, round, benign-appearing nuclei with large nucleoli. 

 

Option B - Ductal papillomas arise from the ductal epithelium of the breast. They have multiple branching fibrovascular cores with epithelial hyperplasia and apocrine metaplasia. The following image shows the histological appearance of ductal papilloma. 

 

Option D - Warthin tumors are benign neoplasms of the parotid gland. They appear as round to oval encapsulated masses. Histologically, they have a dense lymphoid stroma with germinal centers, the spaces are narrowed by polypoid projections of lymphoepithelial elements. The upper later has palisading columnar cells and the lower layer has cuboidal to polygonal cells. The following image shows a Warthin tumor.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a history of facial edema that has now progressed to total body swelling involving the face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet. Urinalysis revealed protein 4+ and a urine protein:creatinine ratio of 3. What is the initial treatment of choice for this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and investigations are highly suggestive of minimal change nephrotic syndrome and the initial treatment of choice is corticosteroids such as prednisolone.

Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years. Its features include heavy proteinuria, oedema, hypoalbuminemia and hyperlipidemia. They may be asymptomatic or can present with peripheral edema. Renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: Maple syrup urine disease is due to a defect in which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is due to deficiency of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKDH).

Leucine, isoleucine, and valine are the 3 essential amino acids, which are branched-chain amino acids. Their decarboxylation is accomplished by BCKDH using thiamine (vitamin B1) pyrophosphate as a coenzyme.

Leucine is metabolized by BCAA aminotransferase to α-ketoisocaproic acid, which leads to the disrupted metabolism of neurotransmitters and amino acids (glutamate, GABA, glutamine, alanine, and aspartate). α-Ketoisocaproic acid can reversibly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation and result in cerebral lactic acidosis. Collectively, these processes are detrimental to the normal function of neurons and glia, clinically manifesting as encephalopathy and brain edema and referred to as leucinosis.

Treatment options include hemodialysis, restricting dietary substances, thiamine for milder forms, and orthotopic liver transplant.

Other options:

B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase: Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase is involved in the breakdown of isovaleryl-CoA, a compound derived from the metabolism of the amino acid leucine. Deficiency of isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase is associated with a different metabolic disorder called isovaleric acidemia, but not maple syrup urine disease.

C. Pyruvate carboxylase: Pyruvate carboxylase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis, a process by which glucose is synthesized from non-carbohydrate sources. Deficiency of pyruvate carboxylase results in a different metabolic disorder known as pyruvate carboxylase deficiency, but it is not associated with maple syrup urine disease.

D. Acetyl CoA carboxylase: Acetyl CoA carboxylase is an enzyme involved in fatty acid synthesis. Deficiency of acetyl CoA carboxylase can lead to a different condition called malonyl-CoA decarboxylase deficiency, but it is not related to maple syrup urine disease.

questions.text: An elderly male patient who underwent a kidney transplant 10 years back is on immunosuppressive therapy. He gives a history of cough and dyspnea for the past 1 week, and the sputum microscopy shows gram-positive budding yeasts cells and pseudohyphae. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Information is not enough for the diagnosis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with microscopy showing gram-positive budding yeasts cells and pseudohyphae is suggestive of invasive candidiasis.

Candida is the most common cause of opportunistic mycoses in the world. Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk of systemic candidiasis, which includes candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata. Clinically, infection with candida can present as cutaneous & mucosal candidiasis, systemic candidiasis, or rarely, as chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

Cutaneous and mucosal infections manifest as thrush affecting the tongue, lips, gums, and palate. It is seen as a patchy to confluent whitish pseudomembranous lesion and is commonly associated with AIDS. Candida may also invade the vaginal mucosa leading to vulvovaginitis, and the nails, and around the nail plate leading to onychomycosis.

Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae (Shown in the image below). It appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Candida albicans form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

When colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37 °C. The image below shows germ tube formation, also known as the Reynolds Braude phenomenon, seen in Candida albicans.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the development of purple toe syndrome, after starting a new drug for the treatment of deep vein thrombosis, is suggestive of the adverse effect of warfarin.

Purple toe syndrome is a rare complication of warfarin therapy. It occurs due to cholesterol microemboli released from atheromatous plaques, which cause arteriolar occlusion. Warfarin must be immediately stopped and replaced with an oral factor Xa inhibitor (e.g. apixaban).
 
Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X and proteins C and S are done by carboxylation of their glutamate residues, with the help of the reduced form of vitamin K as a co-factor. This reduced form of vitamin K needs to be constantly recycled back from its oxidized form for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is competitively inhibited by warfarin. Hence, there will be a reduction in the activation of coagulation factors.

The image below shows warfarin's mechanism of action.

The half-life of proteins C and S are 8 and 24 hours, respectively, which is relatively shorter than the half-lives of other clotting factors, particularly factor II. Therefore, the full antithrombotic effect of warfarin is not achieved for 4 to 5 days. For this reason, warfarin must be bridged with a rapidly acting parenteral anticoagulant, such as heparin, low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), or fondaparinux, in patients with thrombosis or at high risk for thrombosis.

Uses of warfarin are acute deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and preventing stroke or systemic embolization in patients with a mechanical heart valve. 

Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation).

The therapeutic dose of warfarin is monitored by an INR range of 2-3. Warfarin toxicity can occur when the INR exceeds 4 and can lead to fatal bleeding. Treatment includes withholding warfarin, with vitamin K, and blood transfusions or fresh frozen plasma to replenish clotting factors.

Warfarin, LMWH, and UFH do not accumulate in breast milk and do not have an anticoagulant effect in the newborn. They are compatible with breastfeeding.

Warfarin is mainly metabolized by the CYP2C9 enzyme. Drugs that affect the CYP2C9 enzyme can alter the anticoagulant function of warfarin and these include the following:

Reduced efficacy:

  • CYP2C9 activation by drugs: barbiturates, carbamazepine, rifampin
  • Oral contraceptives: increase blood levels of clotting factors

Increased efficacy:

  • Drugs causing CYP2C9 inhibition:
    • Amiodarone
    • Azole antifungals
    • Cimetidine
    • Clopidogrel
    • Cotrimoxazole
    • Disulfiram
    • Isoniazid
    • Metronidazole
    • Fluoxetine
    • Sulfinpyrazone
    • Zafirlukast

Other options:

Option B: Heparin acts by activating antithrombin III, thereby inactivating the active form of clotting factors II, IX, X, XI, XII, and XIII. Adverse effects are bleeding and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) due to the formation of antibodies against the heparin-platelet complex.

Option C: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor. It is used for the prevention of embolism and stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Bleeding and dyspepsia are the most important adverse effects.

Option D: Rivaroxaban is a direct inhibitor of factor Xa. It is used for prophylaxis and treatment of deep vein thrombosis. Side effects reported are bleeding, nausea, hypotension, tachycardia, and edema.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented to the clinic with complaints of  episodic vertigo,  sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and a low-tone roaring tinnitus. What is the possible clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is that of Meniere's disease. It is also called endolymphatic hydrops.

Pathology:
The primary pathology in Ménière’s disease is the distension of the endolymphatic system due to an increased endolymph volume. This can result either from increased production of endolymph or its faulty absorption or both. Normally, endolymph is secreted by stria vascularis, fills the membranous labyrinth, and is absorbed through the endolymphatic sac.

Clinical features:

Accordingly, the typical history involves episodic attacks of true whirling vertigo, which usually are preceded by a variable sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and low-tone roaring tinnitus. 

Examination:

  • Otoscopy - No abnormality seen in the tympanic membrane.
  • Nystagmus - Seen only during an acute attack. The quick component of nystagmus is towards the unaffected ear.
  • Tuning fork test - Indicate sensorineural hearing loss. Rinne's test is positive, Weber is lateralized to the better ear. Absolute bone conduction is reduced in the affected ear.

Investigations:

i) Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA): sensorineural hearing loss is present.  
ii) Speech audiometry: Discrimination score is usually 55 - 85% between the attacks but discrimination ability is much impaired during and immediately following the attacks.

iii) Special audiometry test :

  • Recruitment is positive.
  • SISI score is better than 70% in 2/3rds patients.
  • Tone decay test - decay of less than 20dB.

iv) Electrocochleography: It shows changes diagnostic of Ménière's disease. SP/ AP ratio is greater than 30%.

v) Caloric test: It shows reduced response on the affected side in 75% of cases.

vi) Glycerol test: Glycerol is a dehydrating agent. When given orally, it reduces endolymph pressure.

Diagnosis of Meniere's disease : 

Committee on Hearing and Equilibrium of the American Academy of Otorhinolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery (AAOHNS) classified the diagnosis of Ménière's disease as follows:

Certain: Definite Ménière's disease confirmed by histopathology. 
Definite: Two or more final spontaneous episodes of vertigo lasting 20 minutes or longer.

                a) Audiometrically documented hearing loss on at least one occasion.

                b) Tinnitus or aural fullness in the affected ear.

                c) All other causes excluded.

Probable: 

                a) One definitive episode of vertigo.

                b) Audiometrically documented hearing loss on at least one occasion.

                c) Tinnitus or aural fullness in the treated ear.

                d) Other causes excluded.

Possible:

                a) Episodic vertigo of Ménière's type without documented hearing loss ( vestibular variant) or

                b) Sensorineural hearing loss, fluctuating or fixed, with disequilibrium but without definitive episodes (cochlear variant).

                c) Other causes excluded.

Treatment: 

A)  General measures:

  • Reassurance
  • Cessation of smoking
  • Low salt diet
  • Avoid excessive intake of water
  • Avoid over-indulgence in tea/ coffee/ alcohol.
  • Avoid stress and bring a change in lifestyle
  • Avoid activities requiring good body balance

B) Management in the acute phase:

  • Reassurance
  • Bed rest
  • Vestibular sedatives - Promethazine theoclate , Prochlorperazine , Dimenhydrinate
  • Vasodilators - Inhalation of carbogen, Histamine drip, etc.,

C) Management in the chronic phase:

  • Vestibular sedatives - Prochlorperazine
  • Vasodilators - Nicotinic acid, Betahistine,etc.,
  • Diuretics - Furosemide
  • Propantheline bromide 
  • Elimination of allergen
  • Hormones 
  • Intratympanic gentamicin therapy ( Chemical labyrinthectomy )
  • Micro-wick made up of polyvinyl acetate.

D) Surgical treatment:

1) Conservative procedures: 

  • Decompression of endolymphatic sac.
  • Endolymphatic shunt operation.
  • Sacculotomy ( Fick's operation).
  • Section of the vestibular nerve.
  • Ultrasonic destruction of vestibular labyrinth.

2) Destructive procedures:

  • Labyrinthectomy

3) Intermittent low-pressure pulse therapy ( Meniett device therapy )

Other options:

BPPV is not associated with hearing loss.

Syncope is associated with loss of consciousness.

questions.text: A newborn developed tachypnea and grunting immediately after birth. On examination, the baby was cyanotic with a scaphoid abdomen. A chest radiograph was taken which is as shown below. Which of the following should be avoided in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing herniation of the bowel loops into the chest and absence of bowel loops in the abdomen are suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Bag and mask ventilation is to be avoided in the management of this baby.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect of the diaphragm. Malformation of the diaphragm allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity, hindering proper lung formation and resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia. The most common type of CDH is a Bochdalek hernia and in most cases involving the left side. CDH is a life-threatening pathology in infants and a major cause of morbidity and mortality due to two complications: pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension.

Treatment:

The immediate step in the management is the naso- or orogastric tube placement for decompression. The airway is to be secured with endotracheal intubation (option B) and respiratory distress is stabilised. Bag and mask ventilation may increase the abdominal distension and limit the expansion of the hypoplastic lungs. Hence, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided.

Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) (option A) and high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (Option D) have been used as a part of the ventilation strategy to support respiratory failure. The main goal is to maintain oxygenation to the lungs and carbon dioxide washout without causing volutrauma.

Surgical repair of the defect is to be considered at least 48 hours after stabilization and resolution of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of fever, ear pain, and difficulty in swallowing for 1 week. On examination, there is testicular swelling and his jaw is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with fever, ear pain, parotid swelling, and testicular swelling is suggestive of mumps.

Mumps is caused by RNA paramyxovirus. It is spread from person to person via droplets from clinical and subclinical cases. The incubation period is 12-21 days. The virus appears in the saliva from up to 7 days before to as long as 7 days after the onset of parotid swelling.

The patient presents with prodrome lasting 1-2 days consisting of fever, headache, and vomiting. After the prodrome, unilateral or bilateral parotitis develops, which is tender. It may be associated with ipsilateral ear pain. Ingestion of sour or acidic foods may enhance pain.

It can be prevented by administering live attenuated, MMR vaccine at 15-18 months and 5 years.

Complications of mumps:

  • Aseptic meningitis or meningoencephalitis
  • Epididymo-orchitis which is usually unilateral. Seen in post-pubertal males
  • Oophoritis
  • Other complications include pancreatitis and myocarditis

Meningoencephalitis/aseptic meningitis can occur before, along with, or after parotitis. Most commonly, it manifests 5 days after parotitis. It can present with headaches, neck stiffness, and drowsiness.

*Note: Non-mumps parotitis can be caused by:

  • Epstein-Barr virus - causes infectious mononucleosis
  • Coxsackievirus - causes herpangina
  • Parainfluenza virus - causes croup

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with complaints of excessive lacrimation. Ocular examination showed an abnormality similar to what is shown below. Which of the following organism is likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Herbert's pits. This finding is seen in trachoma which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, more specifically the TRIC (trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis) serovars A, B, Ba, C. 

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage.

The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children and presents with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge (often mild symptoms). Examination findings at this stage show: 

  • Conjunctival follicles containung Leber cells (multinucleated lymphocytes)
  • corneal Herbert's follicles (similar to conjunctival follicles)

Cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. And when the chronic infection with sequelae sets in, the patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia and later blurring, and finally loss of vision. Conjunctiva shows concretions (whitish deposits of inspissated mucus in depressions called glands of Henle). Corneal signs include: 

  • Herbert pits (pitted scars in the limbal which are remnants of healed of Herbert follicles)
  • corneal opacity is seen in later stages.

There can be associated trichiasis ( when at least one eyelash rubs the eyeball) and entropion.

At present WHO grading with `FISTO’ is in use.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion. In case of significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty is done.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

Strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (1–9 yrs)

  • 5 to 10% → FE
  • < 5% → NO intervention

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the signs and symptoms of the condition represented below?
questions.solution:
The X-ray reveals enlarged adenoids, indicating a diagnosis of adenoid hypertrophy. Patients present with a flattened or absent nasolabial fold, not a prominent one.

Clinical features:

  • Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. This leads to mouth breathing. Nasal obstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive.
  • Nasal discharge, sinusitis, and epistaxis.
  • Bilateral conductive hearing loss and serous otitis media due to eustachian tube obstruction.

  • Adenoid facies - elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth.
  • Sleep apnoea - chronic cases lead to hypoxemia and pulmonary vasoconstriction. This consequently leads to pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • Aprosexia - lack of concentration.

Treatment of adenoid hypertrophy follows both medical and surgical approaches. Medical management includes antibiotics for acute infections, antiallergic measures, and nasal decongestants. However, adenoidectomy remains the definitive treatment when medical management fails or in cases with persistent symptoms.

The surgical indications include:

  • Chronic nasal obstruction
  • Chronic mouth breathing
  • Recurrent otitis media
  • Sleep apnea
  • Failure to thrive

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the blood smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum.

Plasmodium falciparum causes malignant tertian malaria. This means that the fever has a periodicity of 48 hours corresponding to one cycle of erythrocytic schizogony. Malignant because it is a more severe and fatal type of malaria.

Major manifestations of severe falciparum malaria include unarousable coma/ cerebral malaria (failure to localize or respond appropriately to stimuli or coma persisting for >30 min after generalized convulsion), acidosis, severe normocytic normochromic anemia, renal failure, pulmonary edema, hypoglycemia, shock, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. Other manifestations include hemoglobinuria, hyperparasitemia, jaundice, and extreme weakness.

Falciparum malaria shows a very high percentage of RBCs containing ring forms. This high-level parasitemia is more often seen in Plasmodium falciparum infection than in infection by other plasmodia. After the ring form in the peripheral blood, the rest of the erythrocytic cycle occurs in the capillaries of the brain and internal organs. So, only ring forms can be seen in the peripheral blood and not the late trophozoites and schizonts. The gametocytes of P. falciparum are crescent-shaped or “banana-shaped” (as shown below), whereas those of the other plasmodia are spherical.

The treatment of choice is artesunate given at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg stat IV, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then daily if necessary.

In Plasmodium falciparum, recrudescence can be seen which is defined as the recurrence of asexual parasitemia. It usually occurs within 8 weeks of treatment and is due to incomplete treatment or drug resistance.

questions.text: In the pressure–volume graph shown below, compliance of lung is represented by _________.
questions.solution:
In the given pressure-volume graph, curve B represents lung compliance. Curve A corresponds to chest compliance, while curve C indicates the combined compliance of both the lung and chest wall.

The equilibrium position is at functional residual capacity (FRC), where the expanding force on the chest wall is exactly equal to the collapsing force on the lungs. FRC is also known as relaxation volume and represents the amount of air remaining in the lungs at the end of normal expiration.

At the point where volume= FRC,

  • Intraalveolar pressure is equal to atmospheric pressure and considered as zero.
  • Intrapleural pressure is negative (-2.5 mmHg)
  • Transpulmonary pressure = Intraalveolar pressure – intrapleural pressure = 0 – (-2.5 mmHg) = +2.5 mmHg.  

For compliance of lung – Pressure considered is Transpulmonary pressure. So at FRC, Transpulmonary pressure is positive (+2.5 mmHg). Hence, B indicates compliance of lung.  

For compliance of chest wall – Pressure considered is intrapleural – atmospheric pressure. At FRC, this value is -2.5 mmHg. Hence, A represents compliance of the chest wall.  

When the volume is FRC, the combined lung and chest-wall curve intersects the X-axis at an airway pressure of zero. Hence, C represents the combined chest wall and lung compliance.

questions.text: A pregnant female at 36 weeks gestation, presents with palpitations, protrusion of the eyeball, and heat intolerance. A chalazion is a chronic and non-infective lipogranulamatous lesion that arises from the Meibomian glands. It is also known as a tarsal cyst or meibomian cyst. Retention of the meibomian gland secretions may sometimes lead to a similar granulomatous reaction. A chalazion may be single or multiple. Patients present with painless swelling away from the lid margin. The upper eyelid is more commonly involved. They may reduce in size, but the complete spontaneous resolution does not occur.

  • At point A, the volume of blood present in the left ventricle is the end-systolic volume which corresponds to about 50 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve opens and the venous blood flows into the left ventricle from the left atrium.
  • At point B, the end of the period of filling—the amount of blood present in the left ventricle is called the end-diastolic volume which corresponds to about 120 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve closes.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction:

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumetric contraction lasts from point 2 to point 3.
  • At point B, the mitral valve closes and the volume of the ventricle does not change as all the valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle continues to rise.
  • At point C the ventricular pressure increases to become equal to the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) and then the aortic valve opens.

Phase III: Period of ejection

  • In the given diagram, the period of ejection lasts from point 3 to point 4.
  • At point C, the aortic valve opens and the volume of the ventricle decreases as the blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.
  • The systolic pressure continues to rise as the ventricle contracts.
  • At point D the aortic valve closes.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

  • In the given diagram, the period of relaxation lasts from point 4 to point 1.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. 
  • This decrease in intraventricular pressure occurs without any change in volume.
  • At point A, the ventricle now has an end-systolic volume of 50 ml of blood similar to the beginning of the cycle.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of events that occur during necrosis?

1) Cell swelling
2) Karyolysis
3) Karyorrhexis
4) Pyknosis
questions.solution:
The sequence of events in necrosis is: cellular swelling → pyknosis → karyorrhexis → karyolysis

Necrosis is defined as the spectrum of morphological changes that follow cell death due to the progressive degradative action of enzymes.

Morphological changes that occur in necrosis are as follows:

Cytoplasmic changes -

  • Increased eosinophilic staining on H&E specimens
  • Moth-eaten appearance of the cytoplasm - due vacuolated cytoplasmic organelles formed by enzymatic degradation
  • Glossy and homogenous cytoplasm - due to loss of glycogen in the cytoplasm

Nuclear changes -

  • Pyknosis - nucleus first shrinks and becomes more condensed
  • Karyorrhexis - fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus
  • Karyolysis - nucleus fades away leaving behind only the cell membrane or empty cells

questions.text: A young HIV-positive patient presents with complaints of fever and neck stiffness. The patient's cerebrospinal fluid sample when stained with India ink reveals the following finding. The organism responsible for this infection is transmitted by which of the following methods?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cryptococcosis which is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. This organism is usually transmitted through inhalation but occasionally also through skin and mucosa.

Cryptococcus neoformans is a round/ovoid budding cell with a prominent polysaccharide capsule. This capsule can be visualized with the assistance of the India ink stain.

Cryptococcal meningitis and meningoencephalitis are opportunistic infections seen in patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). Patients present with symptoms such as fever/headache. Patients are treated with a combination of Amphotericin with flucytosine.

Option B: Cat scratch disease is caused by Bartonella henselae. It presents as a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch.

Option D: Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri is acquired by swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds.

questions.text: A child hailing from China has been diagnosed with Keshan disease. The child is most likely suffering from deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant which complements the role of Vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy is the characteristic feature, but it may also result in congestive cardiac failure, cardiomegaly, and fulminant cardiogenic shock. It is associated with tumorigenesis (increased risk of progression to metaplasia) and atherosclerosis.

questions.text: The following is a histopathological image of the thyroid mass. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, which are findings suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells. Most of MTC are sporadic. Some are associated with inheritable syndromes like familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B, all of which are secondary to RET gene mutations.

Most patients present at 50–60 years and have a female preponderance. MTC secretes calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH).

Features of MTC

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea if there is local invasion
  • Diarrhoea due to increased intestinal motility
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Blood-borne metastasis 

Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid stroma. Raised calcitonin and CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass helps in diagnosis.

Other options:

Option B: The image below shows Orphan Annie-eye nuclei with central clearing and margination of chromatin in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Option C: Follicular carcinoma thyroid on histopathology may show uniform cells forming small follicles containing colloid (resembling normal thyroid gland) or sheets of cells without colloid.

Option D: Anaplastic carcinomas are poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas with varied morphology, including giant cells or spindle-shaped cells or both. There is minimal follicular differentiation with intratumoral necrosis.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

  • Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma.
  • Most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 
  • Mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade; more common in women than men (2:1)
  • Usually cold nodule on the scan
  • Branching papillae and follicles with the fibrovascular stalk, Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes: Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, pseudo-inclusions, nuclear grooves.
  • Lymph node metastasis is common
  • Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma.
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion
  • Most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain
  • Excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

More common in iodine-deficient areas

Mean age of presentation is 50 years

Commonly present as solitary thyroid nodules

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions

Malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion

Associated with P53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS 

miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346) are associated with follicular carcinoma

Histology:

  • Usually solitary lesion
  • Encapsulated
  • Has uniform micro follicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumor thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere.

The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumor recurrence because this thyroid protein should be barely detectable in a patient who is free of disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes with multiple circular, dry, scaly, itchy lesions on the scalp.  On further examination, it is seen that hair is involved but nails are spared. Scrapings from the lesion are inoculated and examined microscopically. Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia seen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of infection involving skin and hair, sparing the nails and the image showing large spindle-shaped macroconidia is a feature of Microsporum.

Dermatophytosis (commonly called tinea or ringworm) refers to infection of keratinized structures (the skin, hair, and nails) caused by a group of keratinophilic fungi, called the dermatophytes.

Dermatophytes are classified into 3 types:

  • Trichophyton infects skin, hair, and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum infects only hair and skin but, not the nails. The species include M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails, not hair. Floccosum is the only species in this genus. Only Macroconidia.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum include:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, the use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellotape (cellotape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.
