questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with the following finding. The discharge from the affected site was positive for Nagler's reaction. Which of the following is not true regarding the tests used for detecting the causative organisms?

choices.text: Shows stormy fermentation on litmus milk test
Shows target hemolysis on blood agar
Elek’s gel precipitation test is positive

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens. Elek’s gel precipitation test is an immunodiffusion test used to check the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, not Clostridium perfringens.

Gas gangrene is caused most often by Clostridium perfringens species. Microscopically it is a gram-positive bacteria without spores (sporulates only outside the human body). Naegler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridium. Sample collection and transport are to be done in Robertson's cooked meat medium.

It is an anaerobe and grows well on Blood agar showing target hemolysis (Option B). A narrow zone of complete hemolysis due to θ-toxin and a wider zone of incomplete hemolysis due to α-toxin results in the development of target hemolysis on blood agar by C. perfringens.

In the reverse CAMP test (Option C), C.perfringens is streaked over the center of the plate and Streptococcus agalactiae is streaked at right angles to it. A positive reverse CAMP test shows the presence of an arrow-shaped zone of enhanced hemolysis pointing towards C.perfringens. α-toxin produced by C.perfringens interacts with the CAMP factor and produces synergistic hemolysis. 

In the litmus milk test fermentation of lactose by Clostridium leads to the formation of acid which coagulates the casein in litmus milk. The clotted milk is disrupted due to vigorous gas production and this characteristic finding is obtained that is called stormy fermentation.

Nagler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridium. The α-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C. perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.

questions.text: A patient with a history of using well water for cooking and consumption presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. On examination, there is jaundice, hemoglobinuria, Mees lines on the nails, and features of hypovolemic shock. A toxicology screen is done, and the 24-hour urine sample is found to contain high amounts of a toxin.  Which enzyme of Kreb's cycle will be inhibited by this toxin?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arsenic toxicity. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (AKG) of Kreb's cycle is inhibited by this toxin, arsenite (inorganic arsenic salt).

α-Ketoglutarate is a rate-determining intermediate in Kreb's cycle. It has a crucial role in cellular energy metabolism as it acts as a precursor of glutamate and glutamine and promotes protein synthesis.

Alpha-ketoglutarate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to form succinyl-CoA and CO2 with the help of the multienzyme complex, AKG dehydrogenase. This enzyme complex requires the cofactors, thiamin diphosphate, lipoate, NAD+, flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), and coenzyme A.

Arsenite inhibits this decarboxylation reaction and causes the substrate, α-ketoglutarate, to accumulate. 

Arsenic toxicity is either due to inhalation of toxic arsenic gas or chronic consumption of foods cooked in contaminated well water. It presents with malaise, headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice, hemoglobinuria, and renal failure. There may be hemorrhagic gastroenteritis, hypovolemic shock, and cardiovascular manifestations such as QT prolongation, polymorphous ventricular tachycardia, and congestive cardiomyopathy. Mees lines is a common dermatologic manifestation characterized by transverse white striae on the nail.

Arsenic toxicity is detected by measuring the 24-hour urine excretion of arsenic.

 

Other options: 

Option A: Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase is inhibited by iodoacetate. It is not a part of Kreb's cycle.

Option C: Aconitase is inhibited by fluoroacetate.

Option D: Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by malonate.

questions.text: In a population study, the value of the mean is 200. If the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between?
questions.solution:
68% of the population will lie between 180- 220.

In a normal distribution curve, 68% of the values lie within the median +/- 1 standard deviation and the mean=median=mode. Since the mean = 200 and the standard deviation = 20:

68% of population will lie between Median +/- 1SD, that is, 200 +/- 20 = 180-220

95% of population lies between Median+/-2SD, 200+/- 2*20 = 160- 240

99% of population lies between Median+/-3SD, 200+/- 3*20 = 140- 260

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

  • Normal distribution is the most widely used continuous distribution.
  • It is also called bell curve (bell shaped) or Gaussian distribution after a mathematician named Karl Friedrich Gauss.
  • The following is an image of three different types of normal distributions.
  • Normal distributions are defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation.
  • The mean, median and mode are all equal in a normal distribution.
  • All normal distributions are symmetric and have bell-shaped density curves with a single peak.
  • Exactly half of the values are to the left of the centre and the other half to the right.
  • The total area under the curve is 1.
  • The density of a normal distribution is more around the centre and less around the tails.
  • There is no skew in the curve.
  • Looking at the figure below, we can understand the empirical rule of a normal distribution which states that:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 1 SD).
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD).
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD).
  • Many data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution.
  • A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

questions.text: A child is brought with hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma. On testing, you find an isolated prolongation of prothrombin time. Which of the following clotting factors is likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma is suggestive of a bleeding disorder and that associated with an isolated prolonged prothrombin time shows that clotting factor VII is likely to be deficient in this patient.  

Prothrombin time (PT) assesses the extrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time (in seconds) needed for plasma to clot after the addition of an exogenous source of tissue thromboplastin and calcium ions. A prolonged PT can occur due to deficiencies/dysfunction of factors V, VII, X, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen.

Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) assesses the intrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time needed for plasma to clot after the addition of kaolin (to activate XII), cephalin (substitutes platelet phospholipids), and calcium ions. aPTT is prolonged due to dysfunction of V, VIII, IX, X, XI, XII, prothrombin, and fibrinogen.  

Thus this shows that factor VII deficiency is associated with isolated prolongation of PT.

Clotting factor VII deficiency, otherwise known as Alexander's disease, is usually inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. It can present with recurrent episodes of bleeding into joints, muscles, and closed spaces that start spontaneously or following an injury. Diagnosis can be made by lab results of PT and aPTT and confirmed with factor VII assay. Patients are treated with recombinant factor VIIa.  

Other options:

Option B & C: Factor VIII and IX deficiency, otherwise known as hemophilia A & B respectively, are associated with isolated prolonged aPTT.

Option D: Factor II deficiency is associated with prolongation of both PT and aPTT.

questions.text: Given below is the demonstration of tetanization in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. Identify the tetanising frequency
questions.solution:
Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 33Hz. In the above graph, we know,

  • The speed of the paper is 1000mm/sec.
  • The y-axis represents millivolts, the x-axis represents time.
  • The scale on the x-axis is 10mm.
  • The area under the graph represents the muscle contraction.

Contraction period (latent period to maximum force of contraction) includes 3 scales = 30 mm. 

As paper speed is 1000mm/sec,

Contraction period = 30mm = (30/1000) = 30 msec. 

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1000/30 = 33Hz.

Tetanization- The features of muscle contraction can be demonstrated by eliciting single muscle twitches. The adding together of individual twitch contractions to increase the intensity of overall muscle contraction is Summation. Summation occurs in two ways:

  • by increasing the number of motor units contracting simultaneously, which is multiple ﬁber summations.
  • by increasing the frequency of contraction, which is called frequency summation and can lead to tetanization.

When the frequency of a contraction reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous, this is called tetanization. 

Tetanization occurs in two ways:

  • Complete tetanus occurs when no relaxation occurs between stimuli.
  • Incomplete tetanus when periods of incomplete relaxation take place between the summated stimuli.

questions.text: A 45-year old man who was a chronic alcoholic presented with confusion, ataxia, and diplopia. What is the treatment protocol?

choices.text: Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of wernicke's encephalopathy and treatment is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose containing IV fluids.

The patient's symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and diplopia strongly suggest Wernicke's encephalopathy, a neurological disorder commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol abuse. This condition arises due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which impairs the function of the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme. The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Thiamine is an essential cofactor for the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase, a key component of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex that converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. This conversion is critical for linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle, thereby facilitating energy production in the body.

Without sufficient thiamine, the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase is severely impaired, leading to an accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood, causing lactic acidosis. This biochemical disturbance contributes to the neurological symptoms observed. Immediate administration of thiamine is crucial in treating Wernicke's encephalopathy. If left untreated, the condition can progress to Korsakoff syndrome, a chronic and debilitating memory disorder. Thus, recognizing the signs and symptoms early and providing thiamine supplementation can lead to rapid improvement and prevent long-term complications.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

    1. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by :

  • Global confusion
  • Truncal ataxia
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Horizontal nystagmus 

    2. Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:

  • Memory loss
  • Confabulation

    3. Beriberi: It can present with sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, and muscle weakness (dry beriberi) or tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure (wet beriberi).

questions.text: Which of the following is false about composting?

choices.text: Bangalore method is an aerobic process
Mechanical composting uses a controlled environment
Nightsoil can also be disposed with composting
Compost has few or no disease-causing pathogens

questions.solution:
The Bangalore method of composting is an anaerobic process.

Composting is a method of combined disposal of refuse and nightsoil. In this process, organic matter is broken down into compost. It has manure value and few or no disease-causing pathogens.

Bangalore method is an anaerobic method and is also called hot fermentation process. Trenches with a depth of not more than 90cm are used for this. This is done by spreading a layer of refuse (15 cm thick) at the bottom of the trench and nightsoil (5cm thick) is added next. Layers of refuse and nightsoil are added alternatively till the heap rises to 30cm above ground level. The heap is then covered with excavated earth. At the end of 4 – 6 months, decomposition will be completed.

Mechanical composting is an aerobic process. In this method, compost is manufactured on a large scale by processing raw materials and turning out a finished product. The refuse is first cleared of salvageable materials. It is then pulverised to reduce the size of particles to less than 2 inches. The pulverised refuse is then mixed with sewage, sludge or nightsoil in a rotating machine and incubated.

questions.text:
A patient presented with tendon xanthomas. His lipid profile showed serum cholesterol levels to be 283 mg/dL and serum LDL to be 202 mg/dL. He was started on lovastatin. What is the likely diagnosis?

LDL - Low-density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia (FH).

Familial hypercholesterolemia (type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia) is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors. This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk to develop atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of FH: 

  • Painful polyarthritis and tendinitis are common.
  • Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over Achilles tendon and the dorsum of hands. Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with 

  • LDL >190 mg/dL, 
  • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or
  • Premature coronary artery disease.

Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins in heterozygous FH patients.

Recent drugs for specific treatment of homozygous FH are:

  • Lomitapide, a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor, and
  • Mipomersen, an antisense oligonucleotide against apoB.

The image below shows Achilles tendon xanthoma and a plain lateral radiograph of both ankles showing bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum respectively. 

 

Other options

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. There is an increased risk for atherosclerosis.

The image below shows enlarged yellow-orange colored tonsils in Tangier's disease.

 

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes type I hyperlipoproteinemia due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk for coronary disease.

Option D: Familial hyperchylomicronemia syndrome is caused due to either LPL deficiency, ApoC-II deficiency, ApoA-V deficiency, or GPIHBP1 mutation. Clinically, patients present with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain due to acute pancreatitis. The retinal blood vessels may be opalescent and are called lipemia retinalis. Increased levels of triglycerides (mostly >1000 mg/dL) is seen. The risk of premature coronary heart disease is low.

questions.text: The gross appearance of the liver observed during the autopsy of a chronic alcoholic, as depicted in the image, is due to the activation of which type of cells?
questions.solution:
The gross appearance of the liver showing classic micronodular cirrhosis seen in alcoholic steatofibrosis is a result of the activation of stellate cells.

Scarring of the liver (cirrhosis) in which hepatocytes are surrounded by fibrosis (with or without a regenerative response) represents a common endpoint for chronic liver disease. The principal cell type involved in scar deposition in the liver is the hepatic stellate cells. 

Hepatic stellate cells are present in the space of Disse and store lipids, including vitamin A. They are mesenchymal in origin but in several cases of acute and chronic injury to the liver, these cells are activated and differentiate into highly fibrogenic myofibroblasts.

The activation of stellate cells can be varied and includes the following:

  • Inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α) are produced by Kupffer cells, macrophages, etc.
  • Altered interactions with the extracellular matrix
  • Toxins and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

These activated stellate cells are then converted into myofibroblasts through signals transmitted by platelet-derived growth factor receptor β and by several cytokines (TGF-β, IL-17) and chemokines. Extracellular matrix deposition and scarring commence in the space of Disse. Eventually, the surviving hepatocytes are encircled by fibrous septa and give rise to diffuse scarring (cirrhosis). Hepatocytes replicate in an effort to restore the parenchyma which gives rise to regenerative nodules, a feature seen in most cirrhotic livers.

There are three distinctive, overlapping forms of alcoholic liver injury:

  • Hepatic steatosis (fatty liver)
    • Fatty change is completely reversible if there is abstention from further intake of alcohol.
    • Starts in the centrilobular area
  • Alcoholic (steato) hepatitis
    • Ballooning degeneration and necrosis
    • Mallory–Denk bodies/ Mallory hyaline - These are tangled skeins of intermediate filaments such as keratin 8 and keratin 18 that are partially degraded and ubiquitinated.
    • Neutrophilic reaction
  • Alcoholic steatofibrosis
    • Perisinusoidal fibrosis and sclerosis of the central vein
    • Micronodular/ Laennec cirrhosis
    • Irreversible

Continued damage of the liver with alcohol progresses to portal/ periportal fibrosis, and then to bridging fibrosis and cirrhosis, which is micronodular (“Laennec cirrhosis”) The characteristic diffuse nodularity of the surface is induced by the underlying fibrous scarring.

Other options:

Option B: Kupffer cells are hepatic macrophages, which are responsible for removing cellular and microbial debris from the circulation, and also for secreting cytokines involved in defense.

Option C: Hepatic stem cells are undifferentiated, pluripotential cells and reside around the canals of Hering.

Option D: The sinusoidal endothelial cells are typically flat cells, each with a central nucleus, and they are joined to each other by junctional complexes. Their cytoplasm contains numerous transcytotic vesicles.

Giant cell/temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the arteries of the head. It is seen in people over 50 years of age.

Hence, the biopsy sample may be taken from the normal part of the artery, leading to a false-negative report. For the same reason, an adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.

  • There is an infiltrate with T cells (CD4+ > CD8+)(option C), macrophages, and multinucleated giant cells (75% of specimens).

Its mode of action has been linked to its ability to crosslink with the purine bases on the DNA, interfering with DNA repair mechanisms, causing DNA damage, and subsequently inducing apoptosis in cancer cells.

It is used in the treatment of testicular, bladder, ovary, and lung carcinomas. However, there are incidences of drug resistance and numerous undesirable side effects such as:

  • Severe kidney injury
  • Hearing loss especially in younger patients 
  • Decrease immunity to infections
  • Marked emesis
  • Electrolyte disturbances like hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia
  • Allergic reactions

Hence, other platinum-containing anti-cancer drugs such as carboplatin, oxaliplatin have been used.

Other options:

Option B- Vinblastin is an M phase-specific anti-cancer drug. Vinca alkaloids bind β-tubulin and inhibit its polymerization into microtubules → prevents mitotic spindle formation.

Option C- Cladribine is an S phase-specific anti-cancer drug. It is incorporated into DNA where it produces DNA strand breaks and depletion of NAD and ATP, leading to apoptosis. Also, it is a potent inhibitor of ribonucleotide reductase.

Option D- Topotecan is an S phase-specific anticancer drug. It inhibits topoisomerase 1 and prevents DNA unwinding and replication.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of vacant stares lasting for about half a minute. The EEG shows <3 Hz spike and wave pattern. The first-line drug for the management of this condition is:
questions.solution:
The EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern, which is diagnostic of absence seizures. Of the given antiepileptic drugs, sodium valproate is the first-line agent to treat this condition. Ethosuximide and Valproic acid are the only 2 FDA approved first-line antiepileptic drugs for absence seizures.

Hyperventilation has a tendency to provoke the absence seizures.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU with fever and hypotension. She has rigours, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea. Her BP is 70/50 mmHg, with a pulse of 140 bpm, and a temperature of 39.5°C. She is minimally responsive. Skin examination reveals generalized erythroderma but no signs of skin infection. Examination per vagina reveals a retained tampon that is immediately removed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above presentation of fever, hypotension, erythroderma, vomiting, and the finding of a retained vaginal tampon, point towards a likely diagnosis of staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a toxin-mediated disease that is most commonly associated with staphylococcal and group A streptococcal infections. Staphylococcal TSS on the other hand is associated with the toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), which binds directly to the MHC II complex and T-cell receptors. This results in a massive increase in cytokines interleukin-2 (IL-2), interferon γ, and tumour necrosis factor (TNF), leading to a cytokine storm. 

Staphylococcal TSS is associated with the use of a highly absorbent tampon. Nonmenstrual cases are seen in patients with surgical or postpartum wound infections, with nasal and wound packing.

Clinical featires include include fever >102 °F, diffuse macular erythroderma with desquamation after 1-2 weeks, hypotension, and the involvement of multiple organ systems(liver, kidneys, gastrointestinal tract, and/or CNS). 

The T-cell activation which produces the cytokine storm in TSS can be seen in the image below:

Other options:

Option A: Rocky Mountain spotted fever is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii. In this condition, the rash begins on wrists and ankles and spread centripetally. The appearance of rash on palms and soles happens later in the disease. Lesion evolves from blanchable macules to petechiae. Headache, myalgias, and abdominal pain can accompany the infection.

Option B: Invasive meningococcal disease presents with meningitis, sepsis (ie, meningococcemia), or a combination of both. Meningitis is the most common complication of meningococcal bacteremia. It usually begins suddenly with an intense headache, vomiting, photophobia, confusion, and a stiff neck. The condition may progress to a coma within a few hours.

Option D: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is a disorder commonly seen in newborns and children. It presents with multiple fluid-filled blisters that rupture easily on applying mild pressure.

questions.text: A 32 year old female who is a  known case of Crohn's disease underwent ileal resection for the presence of stricture. She became a strict vegan post surgery and several months later presents to the clinic with a history of a tingling sensation of hands. Which is the most likely reason for her symptom?
questions.solution:
After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after ileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

In addition to this, a strict vegan diet also leads to vitamin B12 deficiency as meat and dairy products are avoided which are rich sources of vitamin B12.

B12 deficiency :

Clinical features of cyanocobalamin(Vit B12) deficiency (megaloblastic anemia) include:

  • Anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea, or constipation
  • Oral manifestations: glossitis, angular cheilosis
  • Mild fever in more severely anaemic patients
  • Jaundice (unconjugated)
  • Reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation
  • Bruising (thrombocytopenia) and infections (low leucocyte count)
  • Complications in pregnancy: recurrent fetal loss and neural tube defects
  • Cardiovascular disease: cerebrovascular, peripheral vascular, and coronary heart disease with deep vein thrombosis
  • Neurologic manifestations: Bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord (subacute combined degeneration). 
  • Psychiatric disturbances

  • Symptomatic patients show cutaneous photosensitivity
  • The skin becomes rough and red after moderate exposure to the sun and with greater exposure, a pellagra-like rash may develop. The rash maybe pruritic and chronic eczema may also appear.
  • Some patients may also have an intermittent ataxia, manifested as an unsteady wide based gait, which usually lasts for few days, and recovers spontaneously.

Diagnosis:

  • Urine testing for amino acids.
  • Diagnosis of Hartnup disease is made by showing the characteristic amino acid excretion pattern in urine. Indoles and other tryptophan degradation products in urine provide supplementary evidence of the disease.

Treatment:

  • Nicotinamide for attacks

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has a report showing HCO3- = 23 mEq/L, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L. Calculate the anion gap in this patient.

Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. But, a few of the anions (lactate, phosphate, and sulfate) cannot be measured and this is called an anion gap. It is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:

Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ] − [HCO3− ] - [Cl− ]

Substituting the values = 145−23−100= 22 mEq/L

The normal anion gap ranges between 8-16 mEq/L.

questions.text: Which of the following molecular analysis methods is used to detect RNA?
questions.solution:
RT PCR (Reverse Transcriptase PCR) is a molecular analysis method used for the detection of RNA. It can be used to quantitate mRNA levels by generating complementary DNA (cDNA) copies of the mRNA using the reverse transcriptase enzyme. 

The northern blot technique can also be used to detect RNAs. Here, the mixture of mRNA molecules is separated by electrophoresis and then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane and hybridized with radiolabeled probes.

Sanger’s technique:

  • This was the first technique used to determine the sequence of proteins.
  • Sanger’s reagent is 1- Flouro 2,4 Dinitro benzene.
  • The first protein to be sequenced by this method was insulin.

G banding (Giemsa banding):

It is the most common technique used in cytogenetics to produce a visible karyotype by staining condensed chromosomes. It is useful for identifying genetic diseases through the photographic representation of the entire chromosome complement. The metaphase chromosomes are treated with trypsin (to partially digest the chromosome) and stained with Giemsa stain. 

Heterochromatic regions, which tend to be rich with adenine and thymine (AT-rich) DNA and relatively gene-poor, stain darker and appear as dark bands in G-banding. In contrast, less condensed chromatin, which tends to be rich with guanine and cytosine (GC-rich) and more transcriptionally active incorporates less Giemsa stain, and these regions appear as light bands in G-banding. The image below shows a G-banding karyogram of a normal human male.

Western blot, also called immunoblots, is a technique used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized.

  • Treatment - maintaining adequate hydration and forced alkaline diuresis in patients with normal renal function.

questions.text: In a community, there are usually 40-50 reported cases of dengue every week. This week, there were 48 reported cases. This is would classify as:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is an example of endemic disease.

Endemic refers to the constant presence and /or usual prevalence of a disease or infectious agent in a population within a geographic area.

Epidemic refers to an increase, often sudden, in the number of cases of disease above what is normally expected in that population in that area. 

Outbreak carries the same definition of an epidemic, but is often used for a more limited geographic area.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of urinary tract infection. His mother says that he urinates frequently but has a poor urinary stream along with dribbling of urine. On examination, he has a palpable bladder. What investigation can be used to find out the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of the posterior urethral valve which affects only males and MCU is the investigation of choice. 

Posterior urethral valves: 

Features:

  • Posterior urethral valves are the most common cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children.
  • The valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit within them, which typically lie just distal to the verumontanum
  • They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow. A urethral catheter can be passed retrogradely.
  • 15% of boys with posterior urethral valves have unilateral reflux into a nonfunctioning dysplastic kidney, termed the VURD syndrome (valves, unilateral reflux, dysplasia)
  • Diagnosis is most commonly made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder
  • Antenatal USG would also demonstrate oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then babies typically present with urinary infection in the neonatal period or with uremia and renal failure
  • Clinically a poor urinary stream, dribbling, and palpable bladder (due to diverticula) can be present.
  • The investigation of choice is micturating cystourethrography
  • The ultrasound shows the typical 'key-hole sign in which the bladder and the proximal urethra is dilated
  • Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with continuing lifelong supportive treatment of the dilated urinary tract, recurrent urinary infections, and uremia.

questions.text: The process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles and RBC’s, back into glucose inside the liver is called as _________
questions.solution:
The process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles and RBC’s, back into glucose inside the liver is called as Cori's cycle.

Lactic acid is a metabolic byproduct formed after glycolysis in tissues such as the skeletal muscles and RBC’s. The lactate so formed is transported into the liver and kidney. Here, it gets reconverted back into glucose. This entire process is called as Cori’s cycle or the glucose–lactate cycle. 

Cahill cycle also called as glucose–alanine cycle. In the fasting state, there is a significant output of alanine from skeletal muscle, obtained from glycolysis of muscle glycogen. Alanine is derived from transamination of pyruvate obtained from glycolysis. Alanine is then exported to the liver where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis. (Muscle and liver are involved)

 

Note:

Pentose phosphate pathway is otherwise known as Warburg-Dickens-Horecker Cycle.

questions.text: A middle-aged farmer, presented with fever, chills, and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. The smear prepared from the discharge was stained with Wayson stain and the finding is given below. Which bioterrorism category does the causative organism belong to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, chills, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a smear showing a characteristic safety pin appearance on Wayson stain is suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis. It belongs to category A bioterrorism.

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus. The reservoirs of infection are wild rodents like field mice, gerbils, skunks, etc. The important vector of plague is rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis). Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague. 

Investigations include the demonstration of bacillus from the samples of blood, sputum, and buboes. Yersinia is a coccobacillus that exhibits bipolar staining with Wayson's stain. Culture and serology can also be done. Streptomycin is the drug of choice to treat plague, and it should be given intramuscularly in two doses (30 mg/kg). Other preventive measures include regular usage of rodenticides, proper application of effective insecticides, and disinfection. If a patient is suspected to have symptoms suggestive of plague, isolation is advised.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought with loud, raspy, and noisy breathing. His mother also says that his voice has become hoarse over the past 3-4 months. He was born at term through an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The fiberoptic laryngoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of laryngeal papilloma or recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.

It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is caused by human papilloma DNA virus (HPV) types 6 and 11. Squamous papillomas can be seen in children, juvenile papillomatosis (as in this case), and in adults, adult-onset papilloma. 

It is thought that the patients acquire this condition from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus infection during birth. It is usually seen in the supraglottic and glottic regions. Less commonly, the subglottis, trachea, and bronchi may be involved.

Clinically, the patient is typically a young child 3-5 years of age. They may present with hoarseness of voice, stridor, and breathing difficulty. The disease recurs requiring repeated surgical and medical management throughout childhood. Rarely, they may undergo malignant change. 

It is diagnosed using flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and may later be confirmed by direct laryngoscopy or rigid bronchoscopy and biopsy.

Treatment of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis:

  • Surgical management with excision using a CO2 laser
  • Medical management using interferon-alpha has been tried as an adjuvant, but it is associated with significant side effects 

The adult-onset version is usually less severe and does not recur after surgical removal. It affects males more than females and presents between the ages of 30-50 years.

Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic is  having double vision with downward gaze .  She has no other complaints. What could be the reason for the symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests trochlear nerve palsy.

In 4th nerve palsy, the superior oblique is affected, causing:

  • The weakness of depression in eye: Mainly seen when the eye is adducted (depression during abducted position is a function of Inferior rectus)
  • Weakness of abduction in eye
  • Failure of intorsion: Cause of diplopia

The main actions of the superior oblique are intorsion (incyclotorsion), and depression in adduction.

Hence, the patient will have difficulty in looking downwards when the eyes are in an adducted position. Diabetes, hypertension, and atherosclerosis affect the vasa nervosum of the cranial nerves leading to ischemia of the nerves. It results in paralysis.

Other options:

Option B: In 3rd nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve) - Due to the involvement of the superior rectus and medial rectus, elevation and adduction will also be impaired, which is not the case here.

Option D: In 6th nerve palsy (abducens nerve) - Due to the involvement of only the lateral rectus, abduction will be impaired and not depression.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. He was given an intravenous drug, and later, he developed abnormal movements. Which of the following can be used to treat him?
questions.solution:
The development of abnormal movements following an anti-emetic injection suggests that the antiemetic used in this case is probably metoclopramide. Benzhexol should be used in the management of this patient. 

Metoclopramide is a dopamine receptor antagonist used as a prokinetic and anti-emetic agent. It can produce extrapyramidal side effects and dystonia is seen acutely following intravenous injections. Anticholinergics like benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) are used in the management of these side effects. Benzhexol is a centrally-acting anticholinergic agent. It acts by restoring the cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons.

Acute dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by sudden, involuntary, and sustained muscle contractions, often leading to abnormal postures or repetitive movements.  It occurs after intravenous administration, while Parkinsonian-like symptoms develop weeks after therapy. It is managed with the discontinuation of metoclopramide and with anticholinergics or antihistaminics. Irreversible tardive dyskinesia can occur with chronic treatment.

Other adverse effects:

It can cause galactorrhea by its dopamine antagonism. Methemoglobinemia can occur if used in infants.

Other options:

Option A: Hyoscine (scopolamine) is a muscarinic receptor antagonist used in the management of motion sickness and vomiting.

Option B: Cyproheptadine is an H1 receptor antagonist used in the management of various allergy-related conditions like allergic rhinitis, anaphylaxis, urticaria, etc.

Option C: Levodopa is the precursor of dopamine and it is given in combination with carbidopa for the management of parkinsonism.

questions.text: Among the following options, disease elimination can be helped the most by ____.
questions.solution:
Disease elimination can be helped the most by herd immunity. 

When a high level of herd immunity is maintained, the susceptible population is reduced to a small proportion, thereby eliminating the disease. Herd immunity achieved, especially through immunization for diseases like polio, diphtheria, and measles, goes a long way in helping the elimination of disease. A large section of the population would be immune to disease through herd immunity. 

Option A: The purpose of isolation is to protect the community by preventing the transfer of infection from the reservoir to the possible susceptible hosts

Option B: Quarantine refers to restrictions on the healthy contacts of an infectious disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with chronic liver disease presented with complaints of inability to straighten his ring finger completely as shown in the image. The broad sheet-like tendon involved in this condition is the______
questions.solution:
The condition shown above is Dupuytren's contracture. It is the contracture of the flat or broad sheet-like tendon known as the aponeurosis, which leads to flexion deformities of the fingers, especially the ring and little fingers.

The aponeurosis is a pearly-white sheet of fibrous tissue that replaces tendons in sheet-like muscles having wide areas of attachment. They are whitish-silvery in colour and shiny. It is similar to tendons in histology and are sparingly supplied with blood vessels and nerves.

Examples of aponeuroses include: 

  • Palmar aponeuroses on the palms of the hands
  • Plantar aponeuroses on the plantar aspect of the foot
  • Anterior abdominal aponeuroses superficial to the rectus abdominis muscles
  • Anterior and posterior intercostal membranes between the ribs
  • Scalp aponeuroses or galea aponeurotica in the scalp

 

Option A: The retinaculum is a strong, short, and broad fibrous band around the tendons which holds them in place.

Option B: The linear fibrous band formed by interdigitation of the tendinous or aponeurotic ends of the muscles is known as raphe.

Option D: Fascia is a generic term applied to sheaths, sheets or other dissectible masses of connective tissue that are large enough to be visible to the unaided eye.

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.solution:
HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis is defined as inflammation of brain parenchyma caused by the herpes virus, and it typically presents as an acute febrile illness.

Patients typically present with acute onset of fever, altered levels of consciousness, personality changes, and evidence of either focal or diffuse neurologic signs and symptoms, especially in the temporal lobe. Focal or generalized seizures occur in many patients with HSV encephalitis. Other most commonly encountered focal findings include aphasia, ataxia, upper motor neuron or lower motor neuron type lesions, and cranial nerve deficits.

HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. Other investigations that can help include CSF examination, CSF culture, serological studies, MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

The T2-weighted MRI of the brain will show hyperintensity in the temporal lobe in most of the patients. Bilateral involvement of the temporal lobe is more common in HSV encephalitis.

The image below is a coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes in a patient with HSV encephalitis.

Management includes supportive therapy (monitoring of intracranial pressure, fluid restriction, avoidance of hypotonic IV fluids), anticonvulsants for seizures, and intravenous acyclovir is beneficial in the treatment of HSV encephalitis.

 Other options:

Option A: IgM antibodies in CSF - Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

Option B: Tzanck smear of CSF - A positive smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and ground glass appearance. It is a rapid, inexpensive, and fairly sensitive diagnostic test. The Tzanck smear is typically used to diagnose cutaneous herpes infections, such as herpes simplex or varicella-zoster virus. It is not an appropriate diagnostic test for HSV encephalitis, as it does not provide definitive confirmation of the presence of HSV in the CSF.

Option D: CSF culture in chick embryos - It is not a sensitive test used for the diagnosis of HSV encephalitis. Negative CSF viral cultures have no value in ruling out HSV encephalitis. Although this method can be used to isolate HSV, it is not as sensitive or specific as PCR for viral DNA and it can take a longer time to obtain results.

questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with shortness of breath associated with wheezing. In case of aspirin hypersensitivity, which of the following mediators will be responsible for the above  condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has aspirin-induced asthma and it is due to the formation of leukotrienes.

Aspirin causes inhibition of cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1), which would inhibit the formation of thromboxane A2. Inhibition of the COX pathway also leads to the overproduction of leukotrienes since the products are diverted towards the lipooxygenase pathway, which is not inhibited by aspirin.

Apart from this, prostacyclin and PGE2 are also produced via the COX pathway and thus this would decrease by aspirin.

Treatment of aspirin-induced asthma includes leukotriene modifiers and aspirin desensitization.

Aspirin is a non-competitive, irreversible inhibitor of the COX enzyme. It is a nonselective COX inhibitor and inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2. 

Adverse effects:

Thromboxane A2 is an inducer of platelet aggregation and is a potent vasoconstrictor. Hence inhibition of its formation is responsible for the bleeding complications of aspirin.

Nausea, vomiting, epigastric discomfort, and increased occult blood in stools are seen with analgesic doses(0.5–2 g/day). Antiinflammatory doses (3–5 g/day) can produce salicylism characterized by dizziness, tinnitus, vertigo, hyperventilation, reversible loss of hearing and vision, etc. It can cause elevation of liver enzymes and hepatic damage. Hypersensitivity reactions are also seen.

Reye's syndrome is a rare condition that can occur when salicylates like aspirin are given in children having viral infections like influenza.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with severe dyspnoea. Echocardiography showed mitral stenosis with vegetation. The vegetation present on the mitral valve was excised and its HPE image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given HPE image depicts Aschoff bodies, suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease.

Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells, and occasional plasma cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis. During acute rheumatic fever, Aschoff bodies may be found in any of the three layers of the heart. 

Chronic inflammation leads to diffuse thickening and fibrosis of the valve leaflets, often with calcific deposits. Fibrinoid necrosis occurs due to inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations called verrucae develop along the lines of closure. Irregular thickenings present in the subendocardium are called MacCallum plaques.

In chronic RHD, the mitral valve leaflet is thickened, with commissural fusion and shortening. There is thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords. This can lead to narrowing the mitral orifice, leading to a fish mouth appearance (button hole).

The muscle shown in the image is piriformis.

Origin:

  • The anterior surface of the sacrum
  • The posterior inferior iliac spine
  • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
  • Sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion: Greater trochanter of the femur.

Action:

  1. Lateral rotation of the thigh in extension
  2. Abduction of the thigh in the flexed position

Clinical note: Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterised by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramen

Structures passing through the Greater Sciatic Foramen

The piriformis, emerging from the pelvis, it fills the foramen almost completely and is the key muscle of the region.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the Lesser Sciatic Foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus
